instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power
threads.message:
again <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>

again there was some liquid contact in an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> j6100 area. Battery is charging

<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> :3.4 Volt
<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> :3.4 Volt 
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> : 3.4 Volt
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> :3.4

<SIGNAL>SMC_SENSOR_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> : voltage comes and goes 3.4
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> : voltage comes and goes

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power
threads.message:
Do you detect voltage pulse on big coils?
What about <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> signals?
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> pulsing?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power
threads.message:
I'm getting a voltage pulse at L7520, L7430, L7310-20
<CHIP>U1950</CHIP>
pin1: pulsed voltage ( <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>)
pin2: pulsed voltage
pin3: pulsed voltage
pin4:gnd
pin5: pulsed voltage
pin6 Pulsed voltage
pin7:
pin8:3.4 Voltage

<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> : pulsed voltage 0.3 > 0 Voltage

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power
threads.message:
1-2 pulses, or every few seconds (power cycling)?
Test in SMC bypass mode too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power
threads.message:
bypass  didn't work
few seconds (power cycling)?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power
threads.message: What if I inject 5volt from the outside into the <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_FET_R</SIGNAL> line?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power
threads.message:
Check all SPI Bus Termination resistors and their traces.
You can also try flashing known good BIOS.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power
threads.message:
problem solved.
There was a break in the <SIGNAL>SPI_MLB_CS_L</SIGNAL> line
Thank you for your support
